description: Examine the interactions between organisms and their environment.

slides.title: What is Ecology?
slides.content:
# The Web of Life üï∏Ô∏è

The study of interactions between organisms (Biotic) and their environment (Abiotic).

Levels:
Organism $\to$ Population $\to$ Community $\to$ Ecosystem $\to$ Biosphere.

slides.title: Energy Flow
slides.content:
# Sun Power ‚òÄÔ∏è

All energy starts from the Sun.
- **Producers (Autotrophs)**: Make food (Plants/Algae).
- **Consumers (Heterotrophs)**: Eat food.
- **Decomposers**: Break down waste (Fungi/Bacteria).

slides.title: Food Chains & Webs
slides.content:
# Who eats Whom? üçΩÔ∏è

- **Chain**: Linear (Grass $\to$ Rabbit $\to$ Fox).
- **Web**: Complex network of all feedings in an area.

**Trophic Levels**: Steps in the chain.
1. Primary Producer
2. Primary Consumer (Herbivore)
3. Secondary Consumer (Carnivore)
4. Tertiary Consumer (Top Predator)

slides.title: The 10% Rule
slides.content:
# Energy Loss üìâ

Only ~10% of energy is passed to the next level.
- 90% is lost as Head, Metabolism, or Waste.
- This is why there are millions of blades of grass but only a few lions.

slides.title: Energy Quiz
slides.quizQuestion: If grass has 10,000 units of energy, how much reaches the Primary Consumer (Cow)?

slides.title: Biogeochemical Cycles
slides.content:
# Recycling Matter ‚ôªÔ∏è

Energy flows one way, but Matter cycles.

1. **Water Cycle**: Evaporation, Condensation, Precipitation.
2. **Carbon Cycle**: Photosynthesis, Respiration, Combustion.
3. **Nitrogen Cycle**: Bacteria fix nitrogen for plants.

slides.title: Community Interactions
slides.content:
# Relationships ü§ù

- **Competition**: (-/-) Both fight for resources.
- **Predation**: (+/-) One eats other.
- **Symbiosis**:
  - **Mutualism**: (+/+) Both win (Bees/Flowers).
  - **Commensalism**: (+/0) One wins, other unaffected (Barnacle/Whale).
  - **Parasitism**: (+/-) One wins, other hurt (Tick/Dog).

slides.title: Ecological Succession
slides.content:
# Healing Nature üå±

- **Primary**: Starting from bare rock (Volcano/Glacier). Lichens $\to$ Moss $\to$ Grass... $\to$ Forest.
- **Secondary**: Soil exists (Fire/Farm). Grows back faster.
- **Climax Community**: Stable endpoint.

slides.title: Populations
slides.content:
# Adding Up üìà

Factors:
- Births/Immigration (+)
- Deaths/Emigration (-)

**Carrying Capacity ($K$)**: Max population an environment can support. Growth levels off here.

slides.title: Keystone Species
slides.content:
# The Arch Holder ü¶¶

A species typically not abundant but has immense impact.

Example: **Sea Otters** eat urchins. Without otters, urchins eat ALL the kelp forests, destroying the ecosystem.

slides.title: Biodiversity
slides.content:
# Variety is Life üåà

- **Genetic**: Variation in DNA.
- **Species**: Number of different species.
- **Ecosystem**: Variety of habitats.

Higher biodiversity = More resilience to disaster.

slides.title: Interaction Quiz
slides.quizQuestion: A clownfish living in an anemone (protection for fish, cleaning for anemone) is:

slides.title: Biomes
slides.content:
# Major Habitats üèîÔ∏è

Defined by Temperature and Precipitation.
- **Tundra**: Cold/Dry.
- **Rainforest**: Hot/Wet (Most bio-diverse).
- **Desert**: Hot (or cold)/Dry.
- **Taiga**: Cold forests.

slides.title: Human Impact
slides.content:
# The Anthropocene üèóÔ∏è

- **Habitat Loss**: #1 cause of extinction.
- **Invasive Species**: Introduced species outcompete locals.
- **Pollution**: Biomagnification.
- **Climate Change**: Changing ranges faster than life can adapt.

slides.title: Conservation Biology
slides.content:
# Saving Nature üêº

Strategies:
- Protected Areas (Parks).
- Corridors (Connecting fragments).
- Restoration (Replanting).
- Sustainable use.

slides.title: Adaptations
slides.content:
# Survival Skills üåµ

- **Structural**: Body parts (Camouflage, Thorns).
- **Behavioral**: Actions (Migration, Hibernation).
- **Physiological**: Chemistry (Venom, Antifreeze blood).

slides.title: Niche
slides.content:
# Your Job üëî

- **Habitat**: Where you live.
- **Niche**: What you do (Role).

**Competitive Exclusion Principle**: No two species can occupy the exact same niche. One will win.

slides.title: Aquatic Ecosystems
slides.content:
# Wet Worlds üê†

- **Freshwater**: Rivers/Lakes.
- **Estuaries**: Mix of salt/fresh (Nurseries of the sea).
- **Marine**: 
  - Photic Zone (Light, Surface)
  - Aphotic Zone (Deep, Dark)

slides.title: Ecology Summary
slides.content:
# Recap üìù

- Energy flows, Matter cycles.
- Everything is connected.
- **Biodiversity** is crucial for health.
- Humans have a massive responsibility as stewards of the biosphere.
